Results

In this part, you can explore the final results of our analysis.
The results is divided into 2 parts, the first part is the susceptibility map and the second part is exposure assessment.

1. SUSCEPTIBILITY MAPS RESULTS

After performing the classification, we need to assess the accuracy. In order to do that, we performed a script to validate the accuracy of 300 testing points. And here is the error matrix. We can see that the overall accuracy reaches 83%, which means it is a good result basically.

2. Exposure Assessment

Based on the pie chart, we can analyze the population distribution concerning landslide risk levels as follows:
The majority of the population, 72%, faces a low risk of landslides. This indicates that most people live in relatively safe areas with minimal threat from landslides.
However, 28% of the population is distributed across moderate to very high-risk areas. Specifically, 7% of the population is at moderate risk, 11% is in high-risk areas, and a concerning 10% lives in areas with a very high risk of landslides. These populations are significantly more vulnerable and may face severe threats to their lives and property due to potential landslides.
In summary, while most of the population is in low-risk areas, a notable portion remains at varying degrees of risk. It is crucial to monitor and implement preventive and emergency measures in high and very high-risk areas to mitigate the potential impact of landslides. Authorities and relevant organizations should prioritize the safety and preparedness of these vulnerable populations to reduce the risks associated with landslides.
